page.title: 14Day in the life of a sixth former
page.content:
Hannah is 17 and a sixth form pupil. Back in 1985 sixth formers didn’t have mobile phones, cable TV, computers and iPods. Now they’re part of every day life:

Hannah’s typical day:

My school day begins at 8.40am. I get woken up by the alarm on my mobile phone at 7am. I usually watch TV in my room while I’m getting ready (we’ve got Virgin cable).

I don’t often have breakfast and I walk to school with a group of friends.

I’m studying Maths, Physics, I.C.T and Economics. I’m undecided about what I want to do after school, so I’m researching options of both university and apprenticeships. I’m exploring whether to go into business and finance or teaching.

Obviously what’s happening with tuition and university fees at the moment is something that will probably affect me and my friends in the next couple of years.

On a typical day at school I usually stay in for lunch, though I don’t usually take any food with me. I sometimes buy food from the sixth form vending machine or go to the local shopping centre. At the end of the school day I walk back home with my friends.

Once home I go on my laptop and go on facebook for around half an hour. I then either have a driving lesson or do homework/revision.

Once I’ve finished my school work I have my dinner. As I am a vegetarian and my parents aren’t, I tend to cook for myself. My dad tends to cook dinner for him and my mum. I have a takeaway about once a month with friends.

I go jogging twice a week and listen to my ipod while joggnig.

From around 7pm I watch TV or a DVD in my room and I’m constantly texting my friends until I go to bed.

At the weekend I tend to go shopping usually for clothes and in the evening I either go to a party, see my boyfriend or see my friends.


Hannah
